title: Drill: Masculine Changes (-os -> -o)
reading_greek:
DRILL 1: NAMES
- Ο Φίλος -> Τον Φίλο (The Friend -> The Friend [obj])
- Ο Αδερφός -> Τον Αδερφό (The Brother -> The Brother [obj])
- Ο Κώστας -> Τον Κώστα (Kostas -> Kostas [obj])
- Ο Γιατρός -> Τον Γιατρό (The Doctor -> The Doctor [obj])

DRILL 2: OBJECTS
- Ο Καφές -> Τον Καφέ (The Coffee -> The Coffee [obj])
- Ο Λογαριασμός -> Τον Λογαριασμό (The Bill -> The Bill [obj])
- Ο Υπολογιστής -> Τον Υπολογιστή (The Computer -> The Computer [obj])

SENTENCES
- Θέλω τον λογαριασμό. (I want the bill)
- Περιμένω τον γιατρό. (I wait for the doctor)
reading_english:
GRAMMAR: MASCULINE ACCUSATIVE [(See Page 139)](/assets/grammar.pdf#page=139)

1. THE ARTICLE:
   - Only 'Ton'. Never 'O'.

2. THE NOUN:
   - Drop the Sigma (-s).
   - O Kafes -> Ton Kafe.
   - O Nomos -> Ton Nomo.

3. PROPER NAMES:
   - O Kostas -> Ton Kosta.
   - O Andreas -> Ton Andrea.
audio_script:
Let's drill the Masculine Accusative. 

Whatever the masculine noun, usually you just drop the 's'.

O kafes -> Ton kafe.
O pateras -> Ton patera.
O ouranos -> Ton ourano.

Exceptions exist but they are rare for beginners. 

Try it: 'I want the coffee'. 
'Thelo ton kafe'. 
Not 'Thelo o kafes'. That would mean 'The coffee wants...' (which is weird).
